description:
We believe that Argyle is an exceptional school. We are incredibly ambitious for our children and have created a curriculum that inspires and motivates them through our ‘Argyle Adventure’ – a bespoke offer that ties exciting new experiences, educational visits and specialist workshops to our learning goals.

We teach our children to have a growth mindset and that they can have a positive impact on their own outcomes, their community, and the world around them.

Our inclusive approach, combined with academic rigour, means that all children are challenged and supported to attain their very best.
facilities: The school has state of the art STEAM lab
a music room and an art studio. At the heart of the school
the Discovery Zone includes a well stocked library and computing suite. Each age phase has its own playground and key stage 2 pupils enjoy a zoned playground with monkey bars
a football pitch and trampolines. The whole school benefits from our nature garden with outdoor kitchen and wildlife pond.
admissionProcess: Reception places are allocated by Camden admissions. Applications for spaces in other year groups are made by applying directly to school.

schoolViews.text: Pupils are happy to come to school. They are kept safe and feel safe. They said that bullying is rare. Any incidents are dealt with effectively by staff. Pupils are keen to learn and work hard.
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: We have numerous subjects that we can shine in -every day we face different challenges.
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolViews.text: I like Argyle Primary School for my little child, the headteacher and all teachers are really hard working, loving, caring people. I am so happy and been blessed to get admission for my child in this school.
schoolViews.author: Parent

schoolViews.text: Argyle is such a great community school. Everyone is always ready to go the extra mile to give our pupils the very best learning oppotrunities.
schoolViews.author: Teacher

schoolViews.text: We spread kindness.
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolViews.text: Provision for pupils’ personal development is excellent. Respect and tolerance are key aspects of the ‘Argyle code’. These are promoted meaningfully and thoroughly in all aspects of school life
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: From the dedicated teachers to the teaching assistants and admin staff, it's clear that everyone goes above and beyond to create a positive and nurturng environment for the children.Thank you for your comitment to excellence and for making a difference every day.

schoolViews.text: We love our equipment in the playground.
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolViews.text: The well-being of staff, pupils and their families is at the heart of Argyle Primary School. All pupils are welcomed and expected to do well.
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: Thank you for pushing my child to do the best she can!
schoolViews.author: Parent

schoolViews.text: This school is an institution that teaches yoiung children to be friendly, sensible and kind.

schoolViews.text: Teachers have high expectations and strong subject knowledge.
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: Reading is a priority from Nursery
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolHighlights.title: School & community context
schoolHighlights.description: A diverse and inclusive community where everyone is welcomed and supported. An exceptional location in the very heart of London.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupil support & wellbeing
schoolHighlights.description: Teaching is tailored to be accessible and yet to offer challenge to all pupils. Caring staff develop positive  relationships and signpost pupils requiring extra support to an appropriately qualified professional.

schoolHighlights.title: SEND & inclusion
schoolHighlights.description: We foster an inclusive environment with a whole-school ethos, adaptive teaching, differentiated curriculum, and personalized interventions to support each child’s evolving needs, ensuring all students can thrive and make excellent progress relative to their needs and starting points.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupils' achievement
schoolHighlights.description: Pupil achievement compares well to national expectations. Disadvantaged pupils outperform disadvantaged pupils nationally. All pupils enjoy a rich range of experiences and have the opportunity to find their own particular talents.

schoolHighlights.title: Curriculum, teaching & learning
schoolHighlights.description: Knowledgeable and well trained teachers are supported by skilled leaders who ensure that the quality of teaching is at least good and often outstanding. Staff benefit from high quality professional development and opportunities to collaborate with peers.

schoolPriorities.title: Parents as partners
schoolPriorities.description: Work in close partnership with parents so that all parents feel enabled to actively support their child's attendance, engagement and learning.

schoolPriorities.title: Literacy and Maths
schoolPriorities.description: Ensure that all pupils make excellent progress relative to their starting points.

schoolPriorities.title: Distributed leadership
schoolPriorities.description: Increase the school's capacity to grow and improve.

curriculum.curriculumAim:
The intention of our curriculum is to inspire pupils, broaden their horizons, take them out of the classroom and open their eyes to a wide range of opportunities and experiences.

All whilst ensuring that they develop very strong skills in English, Mathematics and Science.

support.childSafetyAndHappiness: At Argyle we are committed to providing a caring, friendly, respectful and safe learning environment for all of our pupils. We promote an inclusive ethos that focuses on respecting one another and celebrating difference and diversity. We follow a trauma-informed approach and work hard to build strong relationships.
support.bullyingProtection:
Bullying and prejudice-based language of any kind, involving pupils, adults towards pupils, staff or parents are unacceptable and will not be tolerated at our school.

We understand the devastating and lasting effect being bullied can have on some children and we will deal with all incidents equally seriously, quickly and effectively, whether it has taken place in or outside of school.

Link to anti-bullying policy
support.attendanceManagement:
Argyle Primary School wants to ensure that all pupils receive a full-time education to maximise opportunities, attainment, well-being, and wider life chances for everybody to realise their potential.

We aim for an environment which enables and encourages all members of the school community to strive for excellence and enjoyment in education. For our children to gain the greatest benefit from their education it is vital that they attend regularly and punctually.

Link to attendance policy

achievement.academicChildSuccess:
The curriculum places an equal emphasis on knowledge and skills and has been designed to be progressive so that the knowledge and skills taught in one unit are built upon in successive units. Wherever possible, cross-curricular links are made so that pupils have time to explore a topic in depth.

Excellent literature and high quality educational visits provide a structure to our curriculum ensuring that children read widely, are read to and physically experience an aspect of each curriculum topic.

The teaching of reading is prioritised. Phonics is taught daily to Reception, Year 1 and Early Readers across the school. At Key Stage 2 children read for at least one hour a day during two dedicated reading sessions. The majority of children will read with an adult everyday. Our pedagogical approach is broadly based upon Rosenshine’s Principles of Direct Instruction: 1. Daily review 2. Present new material using small steps 3. Ask questions 4. Provide models 5. Guide student practice 6. Check for student understanding 7. Obtain a high success rate 8. Provide scaffolds for difficult tasks 9. Independent practice 10. Weekly and monthly review

chartsPerform.chartTitle: % Reaching expected standard in reading, writing & maths at end of primary:

chartsPerform.chartDescription: These progress scores are calculated by the DfE by comparing the key stage 2 results of pupils at this school with the results of pupils across England who had similar results at the end of key stage 1. A score above zero means pupils made more progress, on average, than pupils who got similar results at the end of key stage 1.

SEND.sendSupportInfo:
We are committed to providing high-quality support for children with Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND). Our approach begins with quality first teaching, ensuring that all children receive an inclusive and differentiated curriculum tailored to their individual needs. Teachers use formative assessments regularly to identify gaps in learning and ensure immediate "keep up" support for all students, so no one is left behind.

For children who require additional support, we offer targeted, personalised interventions in small groups or one-to-one settings, addressing specific areas of need. These interventions are designed to close learning gaps and provide focused support across the curriculum. Regular reviews and collaboration with parents and external specialists ensure that the support is continually adapted to meet the evolving needs of each child, fostering an inclusive environment where every child can thrive.

Link to SEND policy
SEND.inclusivePracticeInfo:
At Argyle Primary School, we ensure inclusive practice through a whole-school ethos underpinned by our vision and values, which promote respect, equality, and diversity. This ethos is embedded in our teaching and learning practices, where we embrace adaptive teaching methods to meet the varied needs of all students. We utilise a range of groupings including mixed-ability groups which encourage collaboration and mutual support among children with different strengths and challenges. To further support inclusivity, we allocate additional adults where needed, ensuring that all children, especially those with SEND, receive the guidance and assistance necessary to succeed. We also make adjustments to the physical environment wherever possible, ensuring it is accessible and supportive of students' specific SEND needs, such as providing sensory spaces or alternative seating arrangements. By fostering an inclusive culture, we create an environment where every child feels valued, respected, and able to achieve their full potential.

Link to inclusive practice policy

shortSlogan: A village school in London, inspiring life in all its fullness.
descriptionTitle: A village school in London, inspiring life in all its fullness.
description:
We are a highly inclusive and cohesive Church of England primary school, serving the diverse and international community of Hampstead.

Our strengths include our feeling of togetherness and community, our focus on positive relationships for everyone, and our uncompromising ambition for academic excellence for all.

The breadth and creativity of our curriculum, the enrichment opportunities that run alongside our high-quality classroom teaching, and our innovative personal development and well-being work support all children and families.
facilities: access to Hampstead Heath for trips and PE
activities: after school clubs, including sports, cookery, arts and music tuition
sports teams, with the opportunity to compete in Camden tournaments
admissionProcess: Our children are drawn from both the church community at Christ Church, Hampstead, and from our immediate local area. Please see our website for our current admissions policy: https://christchurchschool.co.uk/key-information/admissions/

schoolViews.text: Christ Church School is a very special place - all the staff are highly motivated, exceptionally capable and very creative. They really care about the pupils.'
schoolViews.author: Parent

schoolViews.text: Christ Church School provides an education for its pupils that is exceptional in every way.'
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: Our children always feel excited to go in, never want to miss a day and have a lot to talk about on their way home. The pupils feel listened to as well.'
schoolViews.author: Parent

schoolViews.text: Pupils said, without hesitation, that they felt safe in school.'
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: School is really fun and all the teachers and T.A.s are kind and they listen. I love how we do a lot of things outside the classroom as it makes school really fun.'
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolViews.text: The bedrock of the school's excellence is the highly ambitious curriculum.'
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: Pupils' personal development is given the same high priority as their academic learning.'
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: This place has always felt welcoming and safe'
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolHighlights.title: School & community context
schoolHighlights.description: At Christ Church, we really do have the feel of a village school, with our incredibly diverse but cohesive community working together for the benefit of all the children. Our location enables us to make the most of all the world-class museums and opportunities of central London as well as the beauty, calm, and space of Hampstead Heath.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupil support & wellbeing
schoolHighlights.description: Our Happiness Project provides children and families with proactive and practical strategies to support positive mental well-being. One highlight is our annual Try Something New week jam-packed with new activities to help everyone overcome anxiety and build resilience!

schoolHighlights.title: SEND & inclusion
schoolHighlights.description:
We include and support children with a range of individual needs across our school. Our priority is high-quality teaching for all in our inclusive classrooms, with teachers making considered adaptations to their plans, resources or activities to support each individual child to make progress. We also prioritise access to the breadth of our curriculum for all pupils, including those with individual needs.

Our SENDCo coordinates additional support and target setting for individuals or groups and works in partnership with parents to liaise with Camden SEN professionals and other specialist services where appropriate.

Our outcomes are well above national figures and we are proud of the progress each individual child makes with the support they receive at our school.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupils' achievement
schoolHighlights.description: Pupils' achievement and progress in Year 6 has been maintained at well above national figures for many years. We are proud of the progress made by each individual child.

schoolHighlights.title: Curriculum, teaching & learning
schoolHighlights.description: Our Arts Project provides the whole school community with the opportunity to take part in enriching and inspirational arts activities, from musical productions and film making to concerts and art exhibitions.

schoolPriorities.title: Progress for every child
schoolPriorities.description: We are focused on providing the highest quality classroom teaching for every child, with targeted and additional support to enable pupils to make faster progress where it is needed.

schoolPriorities.title: Curriculum breadth and quality
schoolPriorities.description: We are prioritising keeping our curriculum of the highest quality and widest breadth possible. We are focused on maintaining our specialist teaching in PE and Music and on providing a wide range of trips, clubs, workshops and visitors, as well as participation in activities with other schools.

schoolPriorities.title: Outreach opportunities for pupils and staff
schoolPriorities.description: One of our key priorities is to develop ways for pupils to make a difference to others, through volunteering, charity and campaign work.

curriculum.curriculumAim:
The design, content, implementation, and evaluation of our curriculum plays a key role in how we make our school vision come to life and enable all in our school to experience life in all its fullness.

The ambitious breadth of our curriculum provision and the links we make across the curriculum, to transferable skills and to personal development, including the development of emotional well-being, spirituality, and a sense of community and responsibility, are very important parts of our curriculum design.

Our curriculum reflects and supports our pursuit of academic excellence for all and our vision for creativity in all we do.
curriculumStrengths: the arts, including visual arts, performing arts and music
PE, with a wide range of sports teams, clubs and opportunities to represent the school
reading - all children are fluent readers, unlocking the wider curriculum, and developing a love of reading for pleasure

support.childSafetyAndHappiness:
Keeping children safe and happy is our highest priority. Our safeguarding policies and regularly-updated staff training set out how we do this.

Our pastoral care aims to support individual children and families with extra support when they need it, and we also teach a wide range of proactive strategies to support positive well-being in PSHE and in our Happiness Project.

Link to safeguarding policy
support.bullyingProtection:
Our school ethos and behaviour policy are founded on positive relationships and we do not tolerate bullying of any kind. We teach children about being an upstander, not a bystander, and train all our Year 5 class as Anti-Bullying Champions each year.

Link to anti-bullying policy
support.attendanceManagement:
Our happy school and vibrant and engaging curriculum encourage high attendance—children want to come to school. Where we need to, we work with individual families, with understanding and patience, to support higher attendance for their children.

Link to attendance policy

achievement.academicChildSuccess:
We ensure academic success through knowing our pupils and their individual needs really well, having skilled teachers in every classroom, tracking pupil progress at an individual level, targeting and planning additional support carefully, and using our own bespoke curriculum with a wide range of enrichment activities to engage every child.

Link to teaching and learning policy

chartsPerform.chartTitle: % Reaching expected standard in reading, writing & maths at end of primary:

chartsPerform.chartDescription: These progress scores are calculated by the DfE by comparing the key stage 2 results of pupils at this school with the results of pupils across England who had similar results at the end of key stage 1. A score above zero means pupils made more progress, on average, than pupils who got similar results at the end of key stage 1.

SEND.sendSupportInfo:
At Christ Church, we support pupils with a range of individual needs to make very good progress both academically and in the wider curriculum and life skills.

We achieve this through open communication with parents, effective target setting, listening to pupils' views, targeted support in the classrooms and skilled adaptations to our curriculum and teaching.

Link to SEND policy
SEND.inclusivePracticeInfo:
Our inclusive practice means that all in our school community can access our broad and enriched curriculum, especially those with individual needs.

Link to inclusive practice policy

shortSlogan: We want our pupils to become informed, articulate and empowered citizens.
descriptionTitle: We want our pupils to become informed, articulate and empowered citizens.
description:
At Christopher Hatton we want our pupils to become informed, articulate and empowered citizens. Through our creative curriculum with its emphasis on the Environment and the Rights of the Child, our innovative teaching and the rich opportunities we provide, children develop the knowledge, skills and attitudes to succeed.

We are a happy, ambitious and inclusive school reflecting the rich diversity of families in our area and are proud to be a beacon of excellence at the heart of our community. Affectionately known as 'Hattoneers,' our children embody high aspirations, mutual respect, and a commitment to making a positive impact. Our most recent Ofsted report highlights our school’s continuous growth and success. We are committed to our school performance and work in collaboration with Camden Learning to ensure the best outcomes for our students, alongside other Camden schools
facilities: Music room and specialist teaching including free guitar tuition from Y4-Y
Separate outdoor learning/play spaces for Nursery and Reception
activities: After school play centre collection with Coram's Fields
admissionProcess:
We strictly abide by the admissions criteria of Camden Local Authority. Details can be found on the websites below.

Christopher Hatton Admissions

Camden Local Authority Primary School Admissions

schoolHighlights.title: School & community context
schoolHighlights.description: We are at the heart of our cohesive community. Our families come from over 30 different countries and we love learning with and from each other and growing new bonds.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupil support & wellbeing
schoolHighlights.description: Our teachers caring ethos creates a sense of belonging that helps all of our children to thrive in a happy, safe environment.

schoolHighlights.title: SEND & inclusion
schoolHighlights.description: Our inclusive practices, welcoming environment, reflective curriculum and well trained staff ensure ALL children can thrive as Hattoneers.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupils' achievement
schoolHighlights.description: Pupils consistently achieve standards above national levels with all groups of children making excellent progress across the curriculum. Adaptive teaching by highly skilled staff provides the support and challenges to ensure all children can achieve well.

schoolHighlights.title: Curriculum, teaching & learning
schoolHighlights.description: Children are taught how to be effective learners with the confidence to embrace challenges and handle setbacks. Our focus on teaching through talk and how to talk enables our children to articulate their views deepen their learning the creative curriculum, supported by specialist teachers, comes to life in our art exhibitions, Earth Summit, concerts and performances.

schoolPriorities.title: KS1 Maths
schoolPriorities.description: Continue to close the gap for disadvantaged pupils in Key Stage 1 maths.

schoolPriorities.title: KS2 higher level writing
schoolPriorities.description: Ensure opportunities enable pupils to reach the highest possible standards in writing.

schoolPriorities.title: Succession planning
schoolPriorities.description: Ensuring staff new to roles have support to develop expertise.

curriculum.curriculumAim:
Our curriculum helps all children to succeed in their academic and personal development. The content is inclusive, reflecting our diverse community and commitment to anti-racist practices.

The curriculum is filled with first-hand, purposeful experiences which allow children to expand their horizons and benefit from the breadth of cultural opportunities available in our locality. Children are encouraged to take on challenges and delve deeper to extend their expertise.

We provide enriching arts and cultural experiences as part of our entitlement pledge that are fundamental to their cultural and holistic development.

Link to curriculum details

support.childSafetyAndHappiness:
Our Hattoneer values focus on creating a safe, happy and fair school for all. Relationships between children, staff and their peers are positive and children are supported to articulate their feelings and views.

There is in-school therapeutic provision to support children when needed and access to wider services. A free breakfast and breaktime snacks are provided for all children. Play spaces are friendly and safe, with opportunities for both active play and quieter areas including a well stocked library.

Safeguarding is central to everything we do; robust practices ensure children are supported and protected.

Link to safeguarding policy
support.bullyingProtection:
Pupils have the right to learn in an environment where they feel safe and happy; bullying is never acceptable and we recognise the impact it can have. We take the time needed to work through issues and support our pupils.

We work with children and parents to ensure children understand the effect of their actions and are supported to rebuild positive relationships. Children are taught about respectful relationships and behaviour through our curriculum.

Link to anti-bullying policy
support.attendanceManagement:
We are a happy school with an engaging curriculum and positive relationships. We strive to create a sense of belonging ensuring children want to come to school.

We know every school day counts so we work with families to support good attendance. Holidays in term time are not permitted.

Link to attendance policy

achievement.academicChildSuccess:
Our aim is for our pupils to be informed, articulate and empowered and to be successful lifelong learners. We achieve this through our curriculum with our evidence informed teaching and the central use of oracy. Through our practice and ethos, we promote characteristics we believe are essential to success.

Using the principles of mastery teaching to scaffold learning, we enable children to progress together. Effective and consistent practices enable our pupils to make rapid and sustained progress across all Key stages and in all areas of learning.

Ofsted noted “The curriculum prepares pupils exceptionally well to take their place as responsible citizens in the modern world”.

Link to teaching and learning policy

chartsPerform.chartTitle: % Reaching expected standard in reading, writing & maths at end of primary:

chartsPerform.chartDescription: These progress scores are calculated by the DfE by comparing the key stage 2 results of pupils at this school with the results of pupils across England who had similar results at the end of key stage 1. A score above zero means pupils made more progress, on average, than pupils who got similar results at the end of key stage 1.

SEND.sendSupportInfo:
26% of our pupils have SEND (3% with an Education Health and Care Plan & 23% on SEN Support). We prioritise high quality class teaching and ensure all teachers can adapt their practice so all pupils make progress. Pupils learn in mixed attainment groups as we have high expectations for all.

If a child needs additional help with an area of learning, support is provided through small group pre-teaching of key knowledge. This helps pupils to engage successfully in lessons.

For some pupils, specific interventions and more significant adaptations may be required. Our SENDCo works in partnership with parents and specialist agencies to plan these.

Link to SEND policy
SEND.inclusivePracticeInfo:
We ensure standards and progress are consistently high for all groups of pupils: girls and boys; pupils of all ethnicities, pupils with SEND and those from disadvantaged backgrounds. This is the result of our inclusive practices and a curriculum that reflects the diversity of our community.

Teaching effective communication skills, an inclusive ethos and the creation of a safe and welcoming learning environment are central to ensuring all pupils can thrive.

Link to inclusive practice policy

shortSlogan: This is a fun, happy, hardworking and successful school. We are proud of the breadth of educational and extra-curricular opportunities we offer.
descriptionTitle: This is a fun, happy, hardworking and successful school. We are proud of the breadth of educational and extra-curricular opportunities we offer.
description:
Gospel Oak is a large two-form entry primary school with a nursery in the London Borough of Camden. It has enjoyed a long spell of stability. There is low staff turnover, particularly in the context of inner London. Overall achievement has been rising steadily and the school is very popular.

Our families represent a very wide cultural and socioeconomic range. Just under half of the children qualify for free school meals and just over half have a first language other than English.

The school was judged to be Outstanding by Ofsted in October 2021.
facilities:
ICT suite
Food Technology Room
Art & DT Room
Sensory Room
Outdoor classroom
Breakfast Club
After School Club
admissionProcess: We follow the London Borough of Camden's school admissions policy: Admissions Policy.

schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolHighlights.title: School & community context
schoolHighlights.description: International Evening, active PTA. Regular coffee mornings for parents, Child and Family Support Worker, pastoral team.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupil support & wellbeing
schoolHighlights.description: Mutual trust and respect between adults and children. Mental health lead. Strong stance on bullying. High behaviour expectations.

schoolHighlights.title: SEND & inclusion
schoolHighlights.description: Our inclusive practices, welcoming environment, reflective curriculum and well trained staff ensure ALL children can thrive as Hattoneers.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupils' achievement
schoolHighlights.description: High standards for teaching and learning. Broad and balanced curriculum. Many extra-curricular opportunities. High quality EYFS provision. High standards and rates of progress in core subjects that are above national averages in KS1 and KS2.

schoolHighlights.title: Curriculum, teaching & learning
schoolHighlights.description: Contexts for learning that are reflected in a high quality, interactive learning environment throughout the school. Broad and relevant curriculum. Outstanding quality of teaching and learning.

schoolPriorities.title: Closing disadvantaged gap
schoolPriorities.description: Address challenges faced by disadvantaged children, including a lack of readiness for learning, low parental engagement due to distrust of school or different values, and potential unconscious biases among teachers.

schoolPriorities.title: Raising standards in writing
schoolPriorities.description: Set up accurate assessment practices to inform targeted planning and teaching strategies aimed at addressing gaps, necessitating a more rigorous approach to teaching and embedding SPaG within curriculum units.

schoolPriorities.title: SEND interventions
schoolPriorities.description: Address lack of structured intervention programs, varying levels of TA training, time constraints for TAs to prepare interventions, and a lack of clarity on appropriate interventions for identified needs.

curriculum.curriculumAim:
At Gospel Oak, our curriculum embraces a topic-based approach to teaching several subjects, building connections between different areas of learning and deepening understanding. While science, history, geography, art and design & technology follow this method, subjects like English, maths, computing, languages, music, PSHE, PE, & RE are taught separately, with relevant links made wherever possible.

Our curriculum also cultivates an awareness of life in modern Britain. Democracy thrives within our school, with avenues for pupil voice through the Junior Leadership Team and surveys. We reinforce the importance of laws through routines, assemblies and behaviour support, teaching children about their value, responsibilities and consequences.

In our safe and supportive environment, children are encouraged to make choices, exercise their rights, and develop cooking skills with a focus on healthy eating.

Mutual respect is central to our ethos, evident in our mission statement and relationships across the school. Tolerance and understanding are promoted through exploring cultural diversity in various subjects and inviting contributions from different faiths or religions to enrich learning experiences.

support.childSafetyAndHappiness: We ensure the safety and happiness of our pupils through comprehensive safeguarding measures, nurturing environments, and fostering a supportive community where every child feels valued and supported in their emotional well-being.
support.bullyingProtection:
Gospel Oak implements proactive anti-bullying policies and fosters a culture of empathy, respect and open communication among students, staff, and parents to effectively address and prevent bullying incidents.

Link to anti-bullying policy
support.attendanceManagement:
Gospel Oak school promotes regular attendance through engaging learning experiences, proactive communication with families, and targeted interventions to support students and address any barriers to attendance, ensuring every child has the opportunity to benefit fully from their education.

Our pastoral support team and Child and Family Support Worker work closely with families to emphasise the importance of consistent school attendance.

Link to attendance policy

achievement.academicChildSuccess: Gospel Oak offers a personalised learning experience to all pupils. We provide additional support where needed through classroom-based and small group interventions. We foster a positive and inclusive learning environment and promote a growth mindset approach that encourages resilience and continuous improvement.

chartsPerform.chartTitle: % Reaching expected standard in reading, writing & maths at end of primary:

chartsPerform.chartDescription: These progress scores are calculated by the DfE by comparing the key stage 2 results of pupils at this school with the results of pupils across England who had similar results at the end of key stage 1. A score above zero means pupils made more progress, on average, than pupils who got similar results at the end of key stage 1.

SEND.sendSupportInfo:
SEND teaching at Gospel Oak Primary School is strong, with a clear commitment to meeting individual needs through well-targeted support. The school promotes an inclusive environment where pupils with SEND receive tailored interventions and make good progress.

Staff collaborate effectively to ensure these pupils access the full curriculum, and improvements have been made in integrating support staff into lesson planning to enhance the quality of provision.

Leadership is dedicated to inclusivity, ensuring that children with SEND feel well-supported and included, with continued efforts to refine and strengthen the support to help pupils thrive both academically and socially.

Link to SEND policy
SEND.inclusivePracticeInfo: Link to inclusive practice policy

shortSlogan: Nurturing, valuing and empowering every child and the community to have the highest aspirations for a successful future
descriptionTitle: Nurturing, valuing and empowering every child and the community to have the highest aspirations for a successful future
description:
We are a vibrant, happy and inclusive school where children thrive at the heart of our community. Children achieve highly and develop a thirst for learning in an environment where mutual respect, tolerance, diversity and inclusion is celebrated and promoted.

Our excellent creative curriculum is enhanced through partnerships with artists, specialists and visits which open children’s eyes to the world they live in and provide the best opportunities to develop their unique talents.

We are proud to be a unique centre of excellence, where relationships are secure and where children grow to be confident, independent and successful lifelong learners.
facilities:
Music Room & Recording Studio
Teaching Kitchen and vegetable plot
2 large buildings with extra teaching spaces
Well equipped outside play space
Rooftop Playground
Family & Adult Learning spaces
Children’s Centre facilities
2 & 3 year old Nursery
Community Hub Space
Sensory and Soft Play rooms
activities: Reading and phonics for children and parents
admissionProcess: We follow Camden Admissions criteria. Details can be found on the school website here: Rhyl Primary School Admissions Policy.

schoolViews.text: Staff know the pupils very well and give them the precise support they need to flourish

schoolViews.text: Positive relationships built on mutual respect abound in every class. Pupils love their teachers because they know they will go the extra mile for them
schoolViews.author: Challenge Partners

schoolViews.text: Pupils make strong progress from their starting points because of the personalised support they receive

schoolViews.text: Pupils behave exceptionally well in lessons and around the school
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: Teachers adapt their approach for pupils with SEND exceptionally well. Expert staff support pupils with SEND in accessing and achieving the high ambitions of the curriculum
schoolViews.author: Ofsted

schoolViews.text: The staff team at Rhyl are passionate about learning and remain dedicated to actively supporting tomorrow’s future today
schoolViews.author: Teacher

schoolViews.text: We go on lots of trips, they're really fun and educational. We went  to the National History Museum and went in the earthquake room, it was scary but fun!
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolViews.text: Parental activities have enhanced my own learning as well as building a network of friends – I love this school!
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolViews.text: Well-being is so good. We get lots of help to feel good and develop our confidence. We can talk to so many people if we need help
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolViews.text: There's always so much going on at Rhyl. The children experience a great range of activities. This all happens alongside a rigorous commitment to high academic standards thanks to a superb group of deeply committed teachers. It is a thriving and happy school for both children and staff

schoolViews.text: The school goes all out to ensure the children achieve their educational attainment alongside social life skills

schoolViews.text: When I was new I felt quite shy but everyone looked after me and  now I've got so many friends. I love it here
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolViews.text: Rhyl supports children with SEND to achieve their best with an adapted learning style for the child – children thrive at Rhyl
schoolViews.author: Parent

schoolViews.text: We get to do  girl's football club, it really helps my confidence.
schoolViews.author: Child

schoolHighlights.title: School & community context
schoolHighlights.description: We are proud of our diverse school and offer wide-ranging family and adult learning, children’s centre, community and family hub provision to the wider community.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupil support & wellbeing
schoolHighlights.description: Excellent individual support for every child from the best staff means they thrive, are happy and well looked after in a safe and caring environment.

schoolHighlights.title: Pupils' achievement
schoolHighlights.description: Our children achieve well and are confident and articulate when they leave. High standards and extensive cultural experiences prepare them exceptionally well for the next stage of education.

schoolHighlights.title: Curriculum, teaching & learning
schoolHighlights.description: Our innovative and connected curriculum gives children extensive opportunities for creativity, music, the arts, cooking and outdoor learning, whilst celebrating their backgrounds and cultures.

schoolPriorities.title: Excellent inclusive provision
schoolPriorities.description: To further develop excellence in inclusive provision in all areas of learning so that all pupils achieve their individual goals, in particular new arrivals, higher achievers and pupils with SEND.

schoolPriorities.title: Develop pupils’ oracy skills
schoolPriorities.description: To develop pupil’s oracy skills to enable them to confidently use effective grammar and high level vocabulary in talk and written work.

schoolPriorities.title: Reading & writing outcomes
schoolPriorities.description: To improve reading and writing progress and outcomes, in particular for disadvantaged pupils, pupils working at higher levels and boys’ writing

curriculum.curriculumAim:
Our curriculum has been designed to enable every child to succeed academically and reach their potential whilst developing as individuals who are ready and prepared for the world ahead of them, from the next stage of their education and beyond to employment and to living in their local and global community.

We provide a broad and rich curriculum so children can make positive choices about their education, social and working life. Children learn through themes and first-hand experiences which are enriched through partnerships with artists, musicians, chefs and employers to enrich their experiences and aspire to greatness.

At the heart of our curriculum is the commitment to prepare children for their future life chances, giving them the confidence and skills that is their social and cultural capital.

support.childSafetyAndHappiness:
The heart of our school ethos is that every child is happy and safe at school and our highly skilled and experienced staff make sure that we create a culture of kindness, respect and consideration for everyone in our school. All children have the right to be listened to and we take time to resolve any worries or issues that arise promptly and always keep parents and carers informed.

Learning mentors, Family Support workers and school therapists are available to support children when needed and we provide support for families to access wider services promptly when necessary. Safeguarding is key to all that we do and procedures are robust and securely in place to keep children safe.

Link to safeguarding policy
support.bullyingProtection:
Children have a right to feel safe in the school environment, physically and emotionally. Bullying and prejudice is never acceptable and is not tolerated.

We understand the serious and devastating impact of bullying incidents and take action quickly to address this if it happens. Preventing and tackling bullying is part of the school’s approach to promoting good behaviour and is supported by our commitment to providing a caring, friendly, respectful and safe learning environment for all of our pupils.

We promote an inclusive ethos that focuses on respecting one another and celebrating difference and diversity, where bullying is never acceptable.

Link to anti-bullying policy
support.attendanceManagement:
We know that attending school every day will give them the best possible start in life and helps them to develop friendships and social skills. We encourage families to have good attendance through positive rewards and recognition and provide support when needed to help children attend school regularly.

We have 2 attendance officers and a family support worker who work with parents and children when needed. We do not authorise holidays in term time and make calls home on the first day of absence to offer advice and help to families.

Link to attendance policy

achievement.academicChildSuccess:
We believe that all aspects of children’s development are equally important and are interconnected. We recognise that children learn best through active learning and when they are interested and involved as participants in the learning experiences presented to them. Children need time and space to develop positive attitudes, acquire concepts and knowledge and to practice skills.

We want children to feel confident in themselves and their abilities. They should have opportunities to experience success and achievement as well as learning through their mistakes in a secure, happy and caring environment. Building Learning Power is integral to our teaching how to be a great learner.

Link to teaching and learning policy

chartsPerform.chartTitle: % Reaching expected standard in reading, writing & maths at end of primary:

chartsPerform.chartDescription: These progress scores are calculated by the DfE by comparing the key stage 2 results of pupils at this school with the results of pupils across England who had similar results at the end of key stage 1. A score above zero means pupils made more progress, on average, than pupils who got similar results at the end of key stage 1.

SEND.sendSupportInfo:
Rhyl has excellent provision for children with SEND. Our Inclusion team is experienced and skilled and we make sure that every child is provided with what they need to meet their individual needs. Our adapted curriculum provision means that learning is accessible to all and children with SEND achieve the best possible outcomes.

Our inclusive provision includes:

  • Sensory, calm and soft play spaces
  • Additional provisions to support language and social communication needs
  • Social skills and life skills sessions
  • Physical and sensory circuit spaces
  • Parenting support and networking for SEND
  • Wider range of interventions and support programmes led by trained staff

We work closely with external professionals to provide appropriate and tailored support and a multi-disciplinary approach to meeting pupils’ special educational needs. Through detailed provision mapping and bespoke provision, we ensure that children with additional needs receive the best possible support in a mainstream setting.

Link to SEND policy
SEND.inclusivePracticeInfo:
Inclusion and the rights of the child are at the heart of our teaching practice. Staff at Rhyl are provided with training, coaching and support to develop and refine the best practice when working with all pupils. We are proud of our diverse school population and our curriculum reflects our children’s backgrounds and cultures as does the choice of teaching resources and extra-curricular opportunities. We recognise that every child is unique and we value and celebrate thier differences. Teaching is carefully adapted and skilled staff adapt learning to meet the needs of a variety of different learning styles in the classroom. Families and the community are welcomed and involved in all aspects of school life to share experiences and to celebrate achievements.

Link to inclusive practice policy
